Message: Lita Edwards, MBA you found an original Green Book in your grandparents' attic?! That's so cool. Makes me wonder what our grandchildren will find when they look back at this moment. Thank you for reposting.
Matthew Ganz well said. all the more reason for folks to get into the game right now üòÄ

James Colten I've felt this. Then I remember going through engineering school with a TI-89 that solved differential equations I couldn't solve by hand. Nobody said my degree was meaningless because the calculator did the calculus. There's a balance for sure, but that calculator made me better because I could focus on the systems instead of the algebra. AI is like the TI-89 for everything.

Matthew Ganz great question. You're asking about the full life cycle, not just code generation. From inside our Kindora build: Claude Code writes tests alongside features. 111 backend test files, Playwright E2E on every PR, Row-Level Security on every table, OWASP-aligned security tests, dual API auth, Redis rate limiting. The AI suggested most of those patterns at my prompting.

Doctorow's enshittification thesis is about extraction. Platforms lure users in, then shift value to shareholders. But that cycle depends on who owns the platform. If the builders are from the community they serve and the users are their neighbors, the incentive to extract looks different. Kindora is a Public Benefit Corporation for this reason. Shareholders can't sue us for prioritizing community value over profit. That's a structural answer to enshittification, not just a cultural one.

Right now I'm focused on prototype, production, and the beginning of the growth curve. Will we need more engineers as we climb? Probably. But by then you have revenue and leverage. Old model: raise millions before you build, then answer to whoever gave you the money. New model: build first, prove it works, bring in capital on your terms.

Kavell Brown I love your provocations! AI is great at capacity problems. Political problems are harder because they're about power, not efficiency, as you know. But I think they're more connected than they appear. The school funding example is perfect. Property tax funding isn't just policy, it's wealth concentration coded into infrastructure. My hope is that if we can break through on building and create real economic power in our communities, the political power follows. Money talks in those rooms. But that requires funders to stop treating our builders like charity cases and start seeding them like the startup ecosystem they are. That's the capital section of this piece and honestly the part that keeps me up at night.
DŒûMar üëæ Brother. \The bottleneck is no longer technical skill. It is clarity
column5: and systems thinking.\" That's the whole article in one sentence. What you've been building with Discriminology is exactly the kind of work I'm talking about. DM me

Message: Nasra Ismail thank you. glad to be in community with leaders like you who constantly push my thinking and keep me honest!

Nipuna Ambanpola thank you! Creating new things with Claude Code is still like magic to me. Yep, I'm that nerd who can't wait to get home to code up the next feature that I know is going to be game changer for our folks üòÖ I hope more folks follow your lead and start creating.
Britney Wehrfritz it's live on Kindora now!! www.kindora.co.
Dreaming is a privilege. But dreaming in a room full of people who immediately start helping you build? That's Camelback. Loved every part of this week.
Excited for everything you're building Toni Fisher. Great spending the week with you.
Ben Toopet thanks for the tag! Byron, we're raising our 4 girls in Oakland. Would love to have you and your family out on one of our Outdoorithm Collective trips!
Rehana Abbas
William Jackson That‚Äôs how it starts. Then you blink and you‚Äôre pushing new features at 2‚ÄØa.m. üòõ  Love watching you translate your genius into the tech side of Village of Wisdom.
Kaitlin Levenstrong Hit me up! I'm doing some AI prototyping and platform builds for clients. Quick, low cost. Happy to help OGO level up üòÄ
Sally Steele Building this was the easy part. You've been doing the hard work for fifteen years. Proud of you.

Michelle Zhang Yes! Download VS Code, install the Claude Code extension, and just start talking to it. It's pretty incredible what it can do! Happy to help you get unstuck if you get stuck. Holla at me.
Stephanie Mansueto thanks for the tag Stephanie!

Taylor Williamson Love how you're nerding out on this. It's genuinely fun to unlock and share.

SQL queries can definitely get you far.

The non-990 funder search is a multi-step beast: source lists (Chronicle of Philanthropy, SF Business Times, accelerator alumni, etc.), build website scraping and deep research tools, use AI reasoning models to structure the data, then deduplicate everything. AI helps a lot, but there's no shortcut there.

Real-time grant opportunities are solvable at small scale. Check out Firecrawl's agent scraper. Much better than browse.ai (which I've also used). Works great until you need to monitor 50,000 websites. Then it gets cost prohibitive, and we're trying hard to keep costs low.

Would love to chat. DM me and let's find time.

Taylor Williamson Love seeing you take the leap into the data! Hope others follow.

At Kindora, basic 990 search is free. It's public data. We charge for the AI layer, but \who funded what\" shouldn't live behind a paywall.

Date: The two hardest problems beyond where you've landed:
1) The matching problem: 70% of 990 filers don't report grantee EINs
Link: so all you have is a name (often a misspelled
Message: abbreviated one). It took weeks of ML jujitsu for me to crack that.

Date: 2) The visibility problem: When Nick and I started at Google.org
Link: we gave through the Google Foundation (990 filer). Google shut that down around 2017. Now none of its grantees show up in public filings now. Had to build a whole smart system to catalogue these \"dark funders
Message: \" which is more and more funders these these days.

Date: The goal is to elevate folks with proximity to problems over proximity to power. The nonprofits closest to communities shouldn't be the ones locked out of the intelligence that wins grants.

Been having a blast building this. Up next: real-time intel on which opportunities are open right now for your specific organization. Thanks to Jose Gordon and his awesome team for helping me build that as part of the AWS social entrepreneur accelerator."

Message: Emily Rasmussen I saw Grapevine on the slide Lizzie threw up at onboarding yesterday and it made me smile! Glad to know I'm jumping into a community with inspiring leaders like you.
Alex Bailey our Black Outside / Outdoorithm collab is next üòõ
Paige Swanstein excited to learn more about your work and more than happy to get you set up with Kindora!
Bryan Lattimore üí´ More reasons for us to kick it fam!

CJ Goulding thanks for being one of the stealth mode testers CJ! it's been such a slog for us in the outdoor equity space. when I look at what we're developing on the Kindora road map, I can't help but feel like help is on the way. we're going to turn things around in 2026.

Alex M. Johnson thank you! come kick it with us in Joshua Tree for spring break üòÄ and feel free to invite your people out. we'll have a few families rolling down from the Bay Area for sure, but the dates line up with LAUSD's spring break, and it's so much closer for y'all. we're excited to be able to offer something for our LA folks.

https://www.outdoorithmcollective.org/trips/de2f48fd-3edf-40b3-ac48-e1ed53e7d6f3

Modupe Akinola You were one of the first! Senior year at UVA, an engineer who knew nothing about consulting, and you showed up for me. Mock interviews, coaching, encouragement. Then a few years later, sitting in a hotel lobby in Charlottesville on a recruiting trip, you read my business school essays and told me to throw the last one away and start over. 100% the right call. I got into HBS. The village you mention started with you showing up for someone you didn't have to help. That's the thread that runs through every transition. Thank you for being part of it from the beginning.
Clif Morgan Appreciate you brother. You've watched a couple of these reinventions up close. The push is real. Grateful for friends who remind me it's worth it when the road gets long.

Michelle Zhang That's how I started raising for our nonprofit too. Super powerful way to begin. As a former funder, I know how idiosyncratic decisions can be. It's very hard to predict whether a grant will be awarded. So you need to go high volume. Last year Outdoorithm Collective applied to 74 grants. We received 8. Tough funding year. But you have to be judicious about where you spend your time and how long each application takes so you can stay focused on programs. That's what pushed me to build Kindora.

Lisa Bourne, MBA Thank you! After a year of fractional leadership and being self-employed, I've got some reflections that I'll hopefully get out here soon. Been thinking about the conversation we had about how to do that well.
Thank you Nasra! Glad to count you as one of the folks in my community as I take this next leap.
I built Kindora after drowning in 10,000 funder \matches\" I couldn't actually use
column5: 000 in our nonprofit's bank account. The problem was real. The path wasn't clear.

Date: Honored to join Camelback Ventures Cohort 16. Thank you Shawna Young
Link: and Elaine Atherton for betting on under-resourced founders building tools for under-resourced nonprofits. Excited to build alongside this cohort."

Message: Victoria Brown that would have been crazy to run into you out there! fun knowing you guys were there too. with all the rain we thought there would be empty spots but it was full!
Bryan Breckenridge Let's get the Breckenridge family out on a trip this year! We'd love to kick it with y'all.

Michael Munoz Acadia is on our bucket list! Love that pic. We're working on creating the infrastructure to roll out Outdoorithm Collective nationally with local leadership and partnership. Stay tuned!

All families are welcome! We center BIPOC families and those who have been historically excluded from outdoor spaces. You don't need any camping experience‚Äîour community welcomes first-timers and experienced campers alike.

Sign up for Joshua Tree: https://www.outdoorithmcollective.org/trips/de2f48fd-3edf-40b3-ac48-e1ed53e7d6f3

Full 2026 lineup: https://www.outdoorithmcollective.org/trips

\Holding the Line: Black-Led Nonprofits and Race-Explicit Work Amid Backlash\" from ABFE and Candid: https://www.abfe.org/blog/letter-abfes-president-ceo-black-led-nonprofits-and-race-explicit-work-amid-backlash"

Rakiba Kibria üíØ Every new technology generates hype about democratizing opportunity. Most deeply disappoint, amplifying underlying divides rather than closing them. But I think AI's first principles create a unique set of forces that could truly close divides. The catch: market forces will work to enrich the few, so harnessing this tech for good requires intentional effort.

Carrie Varoquiers Jean's right. And there's a funding desert right behind this sentiment.

The work falls through foundation cracks: environmental funding goes to conservation; youth funding goes to poverty. What exists at the intersection? I saw this leading at Google.org. Orgs that don't fit the strategy-as-articulated are nearly impossible to fund. But that just means we need to redefine the category.

Outdoorithm Collective organizes group camping trips for urban families on public land (400+ folks so far) and uses tech to help them figure out where to go, what to bring, and how to find community. Positive sentiment everywhere. Resources almost nowhere.

I'd love to see a call to fund this work, so communities whose relationship to the land was intentionally severed can experience nature not just as visitors, but as stewards of public lands that belong to them as much as anyone.
Jennifer Atala This is the work. You showed up with the email address that made people suspicious and earned trust anyway. Grateful to have fellow bridgers like you on this journey.

John Kenyon you're right. The caution is a chance to ask questions that should have been asked all along. The real question is whether funders will pay for it.

I'm learning this the hard way. At Outdoorithm Collective, we're building a social platform rooted in outdoor community, not data extraction. AI lets us build something world class at lower cost than ever before. But it's still not free. Hosting costs money. API calls cost money. Security reviews cost money.

Yesterday a funder loved what we're building, shared a list of their grantees who would benefit from it, then declined to help us pay for it (at least at this stage, which is when we need it the most).

Until philanthropy treats tech infrastructure like real infrastructure, values alignment stays aspirational.

Grateful to share that NCG stage with you.

Nicole Serena Silver This is the part a lot of us miss. The models learn from who shows up. If values-driven people opt out, we're just ceding the training data to everyone else. I've been hearing this out the community and am glad you and others are raising it.

Sabrina Mutukisna \Regular listening parties\" Yes! The tradeoffs feel personal when you're building alone. They feel systemic when you're building in community. Love everything you're doing to create that community here in Oakland Sabrina.

Date: And I'm not touching the Drake debate üòÇ"

Message: Justin (JP) Pasquariello You're naming something important here. The social sector has more leverage than we realize. AI companies need us engaged to maintain social license. That's not charity. That's power. Thanks for the share.
Beth Kanter Agreed, risk vs value is the whole game. Your \hot sauce not ketchup\" reframe at NCG cut through the AI paralysis. Now we need more people to grab for the bottle."

Lindsay Strouse Love this! Silent disco is the perfect bridge metaphor. Everyone's dancing, but you choose your channel. The cautious can start with Tribe (Can I Kick It?) while the bold go straight to Kendrick üòÄ

Jessica Lee Exactly. My understanding is that a typical query is like turning on an LED bulb for a couple minutes. Your grant report review prompt? Negligible. The real footprint is training and aggregate infrastructure, not your individual prompts.

Chris Chatmon what a blessing to spend time with you at the center! Sally Steele has been talking a lot lately about sacred spaces for connection and healing, and KOO Labs is for sure one of those spaces. looking forward to spending more time there.
Taj James if there's one thing I know now more than ever, it's that there's no way to rise on your own. Grateful to be in the circle together.

Date: Here's the crazy thing I've learned after leaving Google: I work more hours now than I did there
Link: but I feel lighter. The weight wasn't just the intensity of the work. It was the cognitive dissonance of feeling like you have to work harder and check your values at the door to be a \"good employee.\"

Date: Money stress is real outside the comfort of a big company. But that weight lifting? Such a blessing.
Grateful for your voice on this."

Message: Chris Genteel üíØ I'm riding high with so much good energy. Just gotta make the money part work üòâ

Funding institutions aren't willing to sacrifice their optionality for someone else's certainty. A 20-year commitment means four CEOs from now, someone you'll never meet is still bound by your decision. That's not strategy, that's sacrifice. And institutions are built to maximize options, not surrender them. How I wish it wasn't so!

Love a good provocation! Thanks Anna.

What a beautiful reflection Xiomara. I can relate to so much of this. I often times felt at Google that my mentors and my ancestors were with me in those board rooms both cheering me on but also holding me accountable to be loyal to the sacrifices they made and the values they instilled. 

This excerpt from a Thomas Merton poem in Richard Rohr's Falling Upward has been a constant source of encouragement to me as I've navigated a path beyond Google.

Be still:
There is no longer any need of comment.
It was a lucky wind
That blew away his halo with his cares,
A lucky sea that drowned his reputation.

It's been a year out here in the wild for me, and it's been beautiful, energizing, and terrifying all at once. And exactly where I need to be. I trust you will find your way as well! Let me know if I can be helpful as you navigate your path.
Rosita Najmi heck yeah! build the damn thing. I love it. we need more folks in our communities taking that entrepreneurial hustle and jumping into builder mode with these incredible AI tools.

Jeff, I felt that pressure at Google.org too. Always go upstream, solve the system, focus on the hard outcomes.

What's struck me since leaving is how little funding exists for something more basic: the ability to trust strangers. To bridge difference. Not upward mobility but lateral connection.

That's what we keep running into at Outdoorithm Collective. The serving you describe changes lives. But there's almost no funding for the infrastructure that helps people see each other as neighbors instead of threats.

The landscape barely has a category for that, much less resources.
Jay Bhatt so great being able to kick it with you and catch up on life!
Love this reflection Sally! That kid at 7am actually caught a trout and woke me up screaming \DAD
column4: IT'S FOUR INCHES!\" My first reaction was annoyance too (I'd been up around the campfire past midnight)
column6: remembering my own first catches with my dad. That's what taking up space looks like. Joyful

Date: Grateful to finally be getting there myself."

Message: Grateful to AWS (Jose Gordon, Kat Esser, Deepika Sharma, Rohini Krishnapura and many others) and Deloitte (Nicole Kelm, Farida Karim Jay Bhatt) for bringing together this community. Thanks to Elizabeth Kelly and Justin Wei from Anthropic for the chance to share the stage. And always grateful to my co-founder Karibu Nyaggah for the chance to build together.

Justin (JP) Pasquariello Love these suggestions. I think we need a revival of sorts around supporting organizations that build up civic values and social bonds. We've been stuck in a rigorous impact measurement paradigm that has emphasized \hard\" measures like economic mobility and academic achievement for a long time. Those are obviously important
column4: but we also desperately need something more fundamental right now. Initiatives that produce social connection and good citizens. I'd love to see OpenAI (and many others) support this."

Message:
Matthew Ganz Good points. In my opinion, the initiatives you cited shouldn't require philanthropy at all. Fair wages for annotators, compensating creators for training data, managing environmental impacts, that's just responsible operations. Whether you have a philanthropy or not, you should be doing those things.

Maybe the real measure of success isn't how much they give away, but whether they build responsibly enough that remedial philanthropy isn't needed.

Amber Banks, Ph.D. Exactly. And even if we get philanthropists who embody the best of social impact, how do we ensure it doesn't simply become legitimacy cover for extraction?

Some acts aren't redeemable through charity. Deciding which ones is the deep moral question nobody wants to touch. God speed to all my people navigating CSR.

Anna Muoio Truth? It's terrifying to ask the question that could put you in the out group of your own field. Here I am suggesting the whole redemptive philanthropy industrial complex (that has fed my family) maybe shouldn't exist.

But here I am in a classic \I'm not saying
column4: I'm just saying\" moment üòÖ Somebody has to say it. Might as well be me. I've seen it from all sides."

Message:
Mark Younger Love this! Our team at Google pioneered a hybrid model, braiding Treasury capital with philanthropy for the Career Certificates Fund ($1B in projected wage gains) and Small Business Fund (enabled 130,000+ loans to minority businesses through CDFIs).

In my experience, most finance folks can't imagine the space between grants and VC returns for startups. OpenAI could pioneer here. Fill the gap between charity and unicorn hunting.

I've been living how hard it is to locate this kind of capital starting Kindora.

Andrew Means, M.P.P. Same! At Google.org, we gained the most legitimacy when our core competencies aligned with our philanthropy. 

But you're right, OpenAI raises deeper questions.

There's good thinking out there about this transition, but I keep coming back to how dignity and worth are tied to creating value for others. Maybe empowering people to wield AI tools themselves (not just reskilling but actually building with AI) is how we make this transition while spreading wealth and preserving dignity.

The difference between being disrupted BY technology and building WITH it.

Gayle Roberts, CFRM I'd be honored. Thank you for thinking of me.

Getting these questions in front of people engaged in this space would be valuable, even if (especially if) they're uncomfortable questions.

Carrie Varoquiers Yes! Saw that. That's partly the point. Most corporate philanthropy funds relief (health outcomes) or infrastructure the company already needs (AI resilience). Both matter.

What's usually missing: funding wealth creation in the communities that created the value AI companies captured. Not just easing suffering, but shifting who gets to build and own what comes next.

Maybe they'll expand over time, and maybe this framework will help them structure that!
Matt Zieger just sent the recruiter several names! what a cool role.
Bryan Breckenridge Ha! So YOU'RE why my raccoon already knew the menu üòÜ
Lee Pham can you believe they gave us the keys to castle at 20? ever thankful for the National Society of Black Engineers and how they empowered us as young people to lead.
Alice Shobe Appreciate that! You‚Äôd know the feeling of cooking in that kitchen.
Adrian Schurr Chef Adrian with the pot! You just gave everyone the secret sauce, soul food family recipe + culinary school üî•

Thomas Campbell thank you for helping Adrian and me see the vision and trusting us to partner on something so ambitious. The way you embraced deep community engagement alongside the exhibition made all the difference. This project remains one of my proudest moments at Google.
Lisa Spinali You nailed it. Yesterday's Michelin star means little to today's critics.

Szu-han Chen From what I can see, we're in a low tide moment for bold corporate funding.

During 2015-2022, there was real momentum. Companies funded narrative-shifting work like Equal Justice Initiative's lynching memorial. Some took on criminal justice reform, examined structural racism, questioned concentrated wealth.

Patagonia's Holdfast Collective and Ben & Jerry's still push boundaries. Costco held firm when 98% of shareholders backed them in January. 

I've also been deeply impressed by REI's Dan Kihanya and Susan Viscon - they're still backing founders historically excluded from the outdoor industry, building real community through Path Ahead Ventures despite all the headwinds. That takes courage.

But overall the tide has pulled back, and most companies have retreated to safer shores.

This work moves in cycles. When the tide's out - like now - you adjust your menu. When it rushes back in, and it will, you ride the front of that wave with everything you've prepared.

Bulbul Gupta Amen! As a nonprofit founder, I certainly have been washing a lot of dishes and cleaning a lot of floors in the metaphorical kitchen this past year üôÉ Some days it feels impossible to juggle it all.

Kevin L. Nichols, this means a lot. For years I got to invest in leaders like you doing the real work. Now I'm the one needing the community's support to build these new things. Thank you for having my back, and for everything you're building with TSEP. Let's keep going!
Lyla Bashan Yes, the messy middle is where the real cooking happens. Most people want to clean it up, make it efficient, reduce the friction. But that friction IS the work.

Yamillet Rivas Yes, the whole dynamic shifts when communities show up as actual partners instead of grateful recipients. That's when philanthropy often gets uncomfortable. We're used to communities being in the story, not writing it.

Gayle Roberts, CFRM Thanks for sharing your experience. The grass isn't greener in CSR, but the money sure can be.

That paycheck motivates a lot of folks to either white-knuckle through the discomfort or abstract it away completely - that's often when CSR becomes expensive theater instead of actual change.

If you're committed to holding the tensions rather than avoiding them, it extracts a price. The job pays well, but you pay too.

Yscaira Jimenez 100% Add a dash of power and a sprinkle of money, and suddenly seeing each other's humanity gets blurred by self-interest. Our minds become remarkably myopic when our interests are on the line.

You're right though, trust between stakeholders is everything. The hardest part is building it when everyone's guarding their plate.

Hector, kicking it with you a couple weeks ago just reinforced what I already knew when you first mentioned this six months ago‚Äîyou're built for this moment.

I've watched you do the hardest kind of work at Google and beyond: directing millions into communities while holding competing truths, building coalitions across real difference, sacrificing comfort for progress. That's not rhetoric, that's your track record.

The early polling doesn't surprise me. People can tell when someone's the real thing.

I'm all in, brother. Let's do this.

I've been feeling that same quaintness in similar spaces, Justin. 

The talking and listening matters. But I'm trying to push myself not to leave those rooms feeling like we accomplished something just because we heard each other.

What if the next step is building something together? Not political action, just... making things people actually need. Libraries that feel alive. Parks where neighbors meet. Networks where people help each other.

I don't know if that's the path forward. But right now, it's the only thing that doesn't feel quaint to me.

JP‚Äîyou're asking the right structural questions. On #1, my hunch is it's about both wealth concentration (can't tech our way out of that) and declining relational trust. We're experimenting at Outdoorithm Collective using AI to help people find and trust each other in community works, but it's upstream infrastructure work, not a quick fix.

On #2 and #3 together: I think better storytelling could close the empathy gap. If donors saw 2-minute founder videos instead of 20-page reports, maybe expectations would shift toward partnership rather than transactional accountability? And the cascade problem might actually be a targeting problem. We all hate ads, but we appreciate being shown the right thing at the right moment. What if AI surfaced causes when people are actually ready to engage, not just blasting them constantly?

#4 connects most directly to what we're building at Kindora: normalize AI-generated reporting so small teams can focus on relationships instead of paperwork. That's the unlock. Automate the drudgery, preserve the human connection.

Amber! Yes, and you and I both know what bridging costs. That's what I keep coming back to: can platforms create proximity directly, or do we need humans who've earned credibility in both worlds to do the weaving? My hunch is the latter, which is why I keep thinking about \following the bridgers\" rather than trying to automate trust transfer. Seems like AI can augment but certainly not replace."
Thanks Tyre! Really appreciate you engaging with the specifics here. The stories piece feels like the unlock, but I'm curious if that matches what you're seeing in your work?

Katia Williams Thank you! That's really kind. You know I'm always eager to hear what data evangelists like you and Stefan think about problems like this üòÅ This trust infrastructure puzzle is a tough nut to crack.

Grateful for the brilliant people who made AI for Giving Design Day such a thoughtful experience.

Loved the conversations and collaboration with (among many others):
- Cecilia Conrad (table-mate & breakout partner & co-conspirator),
- Brandolon Barnett (spark-talk inspiration),
- Shannon Farley and Andrew Means, M.P.P. (co-architects of our Humanless Foundation pitch),
- Hali Lee (ad-lib energy!),
- Jesse Bourns (let's go get that 990 data),
- Simon Morfit (fellow traveler on the journey to democratize AI), and
- Michael Dix, Alison Gazarek, and the Intentional Futures team for shaping and facilitating such an inspiring day.

Thanks for pushing all of us to imagine what trust-based, AI-enabled generosity could look like.

Ben Klasky, this resonates, thanks for writing it!

When your clients overcome paralysis and start giving, are they discovering small, community-rooted organizations? Or more often gravitating toward the well-branded/trusted nonprofits? I've been thinking about how AI might help us close the gap there but curious if you see it as a challenge or not.

I used to have families reach out asking for my grant lists to grassroots orgs, but I recognize that's a form of whisper network that's hard to scale. Curious how you help bridge that gap given that organizations with proximity to problems often lack proximity to donors.
Porcia Chen Silverberg Èô≥‰ª•Ê¨£ that's a beautiful story, thank you for sharing it

Justin (JP) Pasquariello ‚Äî I‚Äôm with you. What I keep circling back to are three disciplines I think we have to practice in public, over and over: naming power honestly, sharing what we have - at real cost (and showing the receipts), and building rules strong enough to check our worst impulses. If we stay with that work (imperfectly, but with faith) the window shifts not through arguments, but through our examples.
Stephanie Linden Seale Thank you for inviting me to the human rights panel! It was a highlight of my week.
Gayle Roberts, CFRM Such a dangerous time to lift up our voices and extend our hands, but it starts with a courageous few.

Jenny Flores Inspired watching you build!! When the world is burning down, our community needs builders to construct something new. Glad to have other leaders on this journey like you who have taken the leap from our privileged roles to start anew.
Julie Ann Crommett Thank you for the opportunity to learn from and facilitate alongside you! What a gift. My mentor as a teen taught me, \he who defines
column4: rules.\" The power to define narrative is the ultimate power. Glad to be reshaping it with you."

Message: Joshua Reiman Agreed. I think what struck me at this gathering was how many successful startup founders who had raised capital on good terms felt they couldn't be as \responsible\" as they'd like with the development of their technology because of the VC pressure to grow and do it fast."
This! Advisors \most value peer knowledge exchange.\"

Date: Yet that wisdom stays trapped in closed circles. When I was leading Americas philanthropy at Google
Link: I was very much in one of those circles myself.

Date: What if we made those trust signals visible? Let advisors and donors \"follow\" each other's vetted orgs like investors follow trades on eToro."

Message:
CJ! You just named the whole game.

When you're sitting on hundreds of grant applications, you lean on trust signals. It's not necessarily wrong. Trust is everything. The problem is whose vouch counts.

At Google.org, family offices would quietly follow my grant lists all the time. It moved millions. But what about your vouch CJ? You have proximity those donors will never have. Your endorsement should carry just as much weight.

Stanley's rubrics help. Panels can help defend decisions. But the new org with messy books and breakthrough ideas rarely survives committee consensus. If I had to put all my grants through committee at Google, I'll bet some of my best work would have been blocked.

The real fix (imho): democratize the vouch itself. Make trust visible‚Äîpublish who vouched and why. Disclose conflicts. Let funders follow trusted leaders like you openly, not through backchannels.

I've been thinking about taking a swing at some tech that could do this.

The old boys' network works because vouching is an efficient way to signal trust. We need to make equitable vouching just as efficient.

Keep pushing this conversation brother. This is the work.

Amber Banks, Ph.D.

Jama Adams Thanks! Really enjoyed your fireside with Baron Davis. When he talked about how the 5% in the corner of the room become the gravitational pull for the other 95% - that insight about how change actually happens stuck with me. Not by appealing to everyone, but by getting that core group aligned.

Julie Ann Crommett this is it. stories bypass our defenses. when someone sees themselves in a character, the recognition hits differently than being lectured. can't wait to dig into this with you and the CGI crew next week!
Chris Knight you know cats like us who've traversed boundaries since birth don't get to pick a side and rest. we've always had to see multiple truths at once!
Aila Malik exactly right. democracy dies when we only sacrifice for our tribe. thanks for sharing your experience from the inside!
Thanks Sergio! Sally's insight about sacred spaces as containers for belonging really deepened my thinking here. Grateful to have both of you as collaborators in the work. Let's go indeed!
Sharp analysis, Gayle. Your \second race\" framing nails it.

Date: One tension: Companies that keep philanthropy in the C-suite instead of separate foundations shape product decisions before they create problems. In my experience
Link: proximity to power beats independence when the goal is systemic change (as long as you have the right kind of leaders!).

Date: Your call for nonprofits to move at AI speed is spot on. The organizations still writing 50-page grant proposals while OpenAI ships daily will get left behind."

Message:
That daily grappling is tough Lauren.

I wish I had clean answers, but mostly I learned that the tension between people-centered work and profit motives never fully resolves. You just try to get better at carrying it. And you pull up every so often to gut check whether your presence is still making a difference or just serving yourself and the system.

Finding other people who understand the struggle certainly helps. 

Ultimately, your discomfort with how things are means you're paying attention to what matters.

Exactly, Allison. The backlash comes from all directions. Those benefiting see you as a threat. Those trapped in scarcity see you as naive. Your own tribe calls you weak, the other tribe suspects your motives.

I've definitely felt this. Called a sellout or a saint depending on who's watching. Neither's accurate, but both dismiss the threat you represent to the game itself.

The mockery is the system's immune response. It means the sacrifice is working.

Amen Matt, the inherent worth piece is crucial.

The person whose politics seems to deny my humanity is still trapped in the same system. We need spaces where we can practice sacrificial love across our perceived divides.
Yes!! If we're going to learn how to sacrifice for one another, it's going to have to happen within sacred spaces. Let's keep creating them.
Miles Dotson Let's build! The energy in that room was just the start.
Cherise McBride, Ph.D. would love to jam with you and the Glover Center. will for sure loop once we've got something.
A convo with Damon on the street last night inspired me to starting thinking of these as studio sessions rather than trying to put together a full on accelerator!

Really great insight here James. Appreciate you sharing your experience. The tables definitely seem to be tilted in the landlord's favor across many dimensions. I've been thinking a lot about how we can shift the power asymmetry here.

Kamala Avila-Salmon ha! we know camping won't be for everyone (though it is for more of us than we think). but the reality is that public parks are one of the few collective spaces left in our country where we can all stand as relative equals. our country used to have more of these kinds of spaces, but they're being privatized. campgrounds is probably the most common space where our four girls have learned about folks outside of Oakland and the Bay Area.
Thomas!! There's no way I would forget an advisee of mine. Glad to see you thriving.
Grateful for you spreading the word CJ!
Chris Kiagiri thank you for setting this whole thing in motion from Karibu's kitchen! love that you're part of the origin story.
Tiffany Hughey, CPA Miss you Tiff! You'll have to join a Kindora meeting at some point so it can truly feel like we've got the old crew back together üôÇ

Kaitlin Levenstrong The Steele family are BIG OGO fans! Drop that beta sign up Kaitlin and we'll get you in:

https://www.kindora.co/beta-signup

Kelly Yun We'd love to have y'all in the Beta! Fill out this form and it will notify our team:

https://www.kindora.co/beta-signup
Ted Chang definitely a blessing to be able to build with a friend you've known half your life!
Yscaira Jimenez That's exactly right! Less time on researching and writing, more time on relationship building.
Leandrew Robinson Kindora x PosterChild.ai: One finds the money, one makes it sing. The nonprofit world ain't ready üòÅ
345 Spear St. alumni doing what we do best ‚úä
Love this Trevor Parham. This is exactly why Oakstop matters. Not just space, but infrastructure for collisions and breakthroughs. Let's keep building!

Love this! The real measure of gear isn't how long it lasts, it's how thoroughly it gets used. 

That hammock you mentioned is actually the replacement! The original Nemo  became the gravitational center of every campsite until the kids literally loved it to death like a beloved stuffed animal. Those straps y'all were sorting will hopefully survive the next round of enthusiastic overuse.

Shout out to NEMO Equipment for standing behind products that kids wear out from joy.

The response to this has been great. Thank you all for the insights and offers to help!

I've turned your collective input into a draft concept: SafeSign, an open-source concept for democratizing commercial lease intelligence. The brief is here:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/18GNFLc7bfLzrfar1oXZ0HmHtv37ueKc0RqaBJoLX7Gg/edit?usp=sharing

Very much a living document. Add your expertise, challenge our assumptions, make it better. This is what \collisions\" can create when we build together.

Date: Let's keep going üöÄ"

Message: Love seeing this vision come to life, Dan! As we've worked together on the grant-making framework, I've been consistently impressed by how thoughtfully Flourish Fund is approaching this launch. Looking forward to collaborating closely with the new Senior Program Manager and Community Lead in particular. Excited to see who joins the team!
Emerald Bay delivered. Four girls who now know those sunrises are theirs too. Thank you all for seeing what we see. Your support keeps us pushing forward.

Sally Your courage to build something new through skeptics, chaos, campfires, and countless pivots (plus our kids' infinite interruptions) inspires me daily. Love figuring it out together. This recognition is just the beginning. ‚úäüèæ
Itzbeth (Itzy) Menj√≠var that Thich Nhat Hanh quote is üî•
Bryan Breckenridge idyllic!! love that y'all are getting out there this summer.
https://www.greenwoodave.com/products/issue-no-6

So glad you found your perfect digital detox spot, Carrie!

For anyone else seeking hidden gems like this check out the social enterprise I started with my wife Sally Steele www.outdoorithm.com/map. We've analyzed millions of camper reviews with AI to surface the best spots. Just filter for 'Top-Rated' + 'Less Visited' to find those peaceful places where you can truly unplug. We're on a mission to make camping more accessible, especially for families.

Jessica Li - exactly, mostly word of mouth. Stephanie Mansueto is right that this trend is happening across corporate functions.

What I'm seeing: organizations post full-time roles, can't find the right fit or budget, then someone suggests \what about fractional?\" Often it's an \"aha\" moment. They get senior strategic thinking without the full-time commitment.

column4: but once they understand the model

Link: we'll see more formal processes. Right now it's very relationship-driven."

Message:
Thanks for the tag, Stephanie. Your point about CSR teams getting leaner while responsibilities expand resonates. Over my last several years at Google.org, my team's grantmaking budget tripled while we were on a hiring freeze.

One thing I'm seeing from my new vantage point as a fractional Chief Impact Officer: many organizations are realizing they need senior-level strategic thinking but can't justify a full-time executive role. This is creating interesting opportunities for experienced CSR professionals to work across multiple organizations rather than being tied to just one.

Matthew Aronson Same - I rarely wore the gear either. Felt complicated.

But you nailed it: our liberations really are tied together. Maybe it's time to dust off those hoodies. Not out of pride in perfect institutions, but to defend the doors they opened for us.
Malia Griggs-Murphy We lifted each other and made everything we touched stronger, and that's exactly what they're trying to end.
Corey Marshall Exactly right. It's the whole system. Tear down, privatize what's left, then shape who gets access.
Here's a link to the Benevity Impact Labs - 2025 State of Corporate Purpose: https://benevity.com/state-of-corporate-purpose-2025
Peta-Gay Clarke love that wisdom from the elders! good words.

This resonates.

What I'm left thinking about is the colleague who says \it's just business\" when principle is on the line. The ones who've learned to divorce their humanity from their job description‚Äîwho never received grace
column4: so offer none. Who tell themselves they owe nothing beyond what they were given.

Date: When does self-preservation become complicity?"

Message: Leandrew Robinson was just thinking about you and PosterChild. we should definitely catch up!

Yes, Monisha Kapila, I'm seeing the same. For sure, there are real moral conundrums here. But if we don't jump in, the game gets played without us.

The biggest risk, imho, is wealth concentration. The only way I see preventing that is getting more generosity-minded folks building these tools while we still can.

Exactly, Adam Rich. We're moving from a world where you needed to convince gatekeepers you had a good idea, to one where you can just build it and let the market decide.

The messiness is real - not everyone will make this transition. But I really hope we can get some of our most innovative problem solvers off the sidelines and into the AI game.

Daisy Auger-Dom√≠nguez (she/her/ella) Well said! I'm grateful for fellow leaders like you who've demonstrated that we can honor both our values and organizational goals when we refuse to fragment ourselves.
Ha! Thanks Harriet Gardner, if you know any funders who'd bankroll Justin.org, send them my way! üòÑ
Congratulations! Living on the Lawn was a highlight of my time at UVA. We had an amazing run of Black students living in 9 West Jade Craig

I can definitely relate to this Justin Barra. When I moved from directing Google's philanthropy to fractional leadership, I felt that tension. Knowledge can become an idol we worship, but real transformation happens when we stand in the gap between expertise and execution. I've learned to value my ability to create systems change more than being the smartest person in the room‚Äîthough that doesn't stop the occasional voice whispering \who are you to lead this?\" Those moments of self-doubt are where the real growth happens."
Well deserved John. Twenty years of unwavering commitment speaks for itself. Success is never achieved alone, and you and MLT were a cornerstone I built upon.
Love the full circle moment and seeing you lead the next generation Quentin Washington. Ridley changed my life. Such an important program.

Kat Gabrielle Sadasia McCutchen this is dope! Kat, I'm building something similar for the nonprofit sector, and as Sadasia mentioned, have wondered if anything existed around investors as I'm part of some community development projects that could use this kind of support. happy to compare notes and explore partnership if you're interested.

Appreciate the deep wrestling here. The framing assumes companies must justify social impact solely through business value, but this premise deserves examination. 

Companies exist within social ecosystems that enable their functioning through infrastructure, educated workforces, and legal frameworks.

The most enduring companies recognize they're civic participants with obligations extending beyond quarterly earnings. Their social license to operate isn't just nice-to-have, but fundamentally intertwined with long-term viability.

Perhaps we should focus less on making the business case for social impact (though I'm deeply familiar with the many ways to do that), and more on reimagining what legitimate business success looks like in the first place.

Erin L. Worsham Thanks for your insightful feedback! Regarding the thermostat, it‚Äôs definitely an apprenticed skill. You need to carefully observe authority figures who are responsible for stability, and understand how far you can push without tipping the balance. My best classroom training was through Ron Heifetz‚Äôs experiential class at Harvard Kennedy School, where we practiced this balancing act firsthand‚Äîrealizing that leadership is about feeling your way through uncertainty, rather than just reading about it. I'm sure you can Google some firsthand accounts of some of thing unconventional things Prof. Heifetz put us through in the class. There were some WILD days in there.
J. M. Johnson Well said, and thank you for posting Lyel and Wilneida's article on public interest tech. I return to that article often.
Nona Yehia well said!
Love seeing these insights Amy! What specifically is Van cooking on to make Wakanda real? I'm intrigued.

On the Overton window - it's exactly like managing the temperature of the room! Picture having a window open on a cool day - you can crank that thermostat way up without overheating the room. But if the window is closed? Things get uncomfortably hot real quick.

The social climate works the same way. When society's \window\" is open to certain conversations
column4: you can dial up the heat on those issues substantially. When it's closed
column5: even a slight temperature increase can trigger resistance. Developing this intuition is crucial - noticing when senior leaders start fanning themselves is your cue that you might be approaching the limit for that moment. The art is keeping it warm enough for growth without triggering the organizational equivalent of throwing the breaker."

Message:
Kavell Brown Coming from the king of LinkedIn bars himself, that's high praise. I'm just trying to keep up with your flow!

For me, courage to accept risk comes from internal and external sources. Internally, there's that fire in the belly - a conviction I've learned to channel constructively. This requires awareness of when that fire serves justice versus when it might become destructive. I feel the truth in my body, and it physically weighs on me to hold it in.

Externally, my responsibility correlates with privilege - not just financial stability, but also emotional resilience and support networks to weather pushback. 

Then there's agency - enough influence that your courage might actually move the needle.

When I examine these factors in my life, I recognize my high responsibility to lead and try not to shirk that call.

Perhaps most importantly, I believe something bigger than us is bending the moral arc toward justice. This faith gives me confidence that doing what's right, even when painful short-term, aligns with how things should unfold.

I've got lots more I could share on this topic! Let me know if you'd like me to put pen to paper on it üôÇ

For those interested in seeing Bryan Stevenson's powerful TGIF talk that I referenced in this article, here's the recording. His message about the necessity of doing uncomfortable things to create justice is just as relevant today as it was then. Well worth 25 minutes of your time:

https://youtu.be/sWWyT8iQU3M?si=yDNMmxIQjr5MNuU3
Charla√© Washington Thanks Charla√©. Looking back, I now realize what a unique moment in history we were in, where there was space to pursue that kind of work. Much less so today.

Maurice Matthews, PMP, CSSGB I love that the juggling metaphor still resonates with you! Credit goes to Howard Stevenson, who originally shared that brilliant analogy. Often, it's our relationships that are fragile and irreplaceable. That's why great leaders always pay close attention to how their decisions impact the human connections around them. You've always deeply understood this, and I appreciate you sharing how it's stayed with you. I miss running Monday Morning Kickoffs and Friday Feedbacks with you üòÄ

Shaun Tai ¬†Your leadership at BRIDGEGOOD has always been a real-life example of what I'm talking about‚Äîcourageously stepping into uncertainty to create meaningful impact. Jose Gordon and I were just reminiscing at his AWS offsite about those early days in Oakland, dreaming big (#moonshots!) in your office. Grateful for your continued inspiration and friendship.

Bryan Breckenridge What a time to be alive and shaping tech philanthropy together in the late 2010s, right? I'll never forget your iconic sky-blue Box.org suit‚Äîtruly legendary! Always grateful for your leadership and camaraderie.

Olatunde Sobomehin For sure. One of the things that gets me excited about the new opportunities opening up with AI is that our communities can start solving problems they experience without needing to grab the attention of a big tech company. We can build for us! I'll DM you.

Excited to see what you write about this moment, Jeff. We need new thinking! As hard as this moment is, I can't help but see it as both a profound challenge and an opportunity for renewal.

As bell hooks reminds us: \To be truly visionary we have to root our imagination in our concrete reality while simultaneously imagining possibilities beyond that reality.\"

Date: I'm hopeful that from this difficult season will emerge leaders who can both honor what works and boldly create what's next. In these times
Link: I find myself simultaneously alarmed by what's eroding and energized by the creative possibilities that emerge when old structures give way and new technologies enable approaches we once thought impossible.¬†"

Message: Kamala Avila-Salmon Thank you for this powerful reflection. You embody so much of what I feel deep in my bones is needed right now. There's something uniquely challenging about choosing to step away from institutional scale to build something new, especially when you've seen firsthand how that scale can amplify impact. I love how you're approaching it - meeting storytellers at the source, nurturing their work in a protected space first. It's more than a little terrifying stepping out on our own, but the more of us who start building new things with our hard-earned knowledge of how to navigate institutions and leverage power, the more hope I have for what might emerge from this moment. Looking forward to seeing what you create!
Thank you for representing this in such a beautiful and visual way! Honored to be in solidarity with you all.

Amazing to see you engaged with Defy Nimmi! I started partnering with them back in 2014 and have met so many of their amazing EITs. What's cool is that now I bump into EITs on the outside in daily life. I was riding the Oakland ferry just the other month and ran into one of the guys I coached and had a chance to catch up and hear about how well he's doing for himself.

Sara Allan You're right - it's a hard truth to face that capitalism, if left alone, will narrowly serve the self-interested bottom line and drop moral values the moment they become inconvenient. This moment is making that painfully clear. But then I remind myself that the rules governing capitalism aren't natural laws - they're made by humans, and humans can change them. We've seen this throughout history: workers fought for the weekend, Black Americans demanded equal access to jobs and loans, communities forced companies to stop poisoning our air and water.

Since it's a game we invented, not a force of nature, where are the greatest points of leverage to nudge the system toward moral outcomes? During eras when our institutions are letting capitalism run unchecked and government's role as counterweight is shrinking, I'm starting to believe our energy is best spent building new models that show a different way is possible - protected spaces where we can grow something better, proving there are alternatives to a system that puts profits over people. Sounds like you're landing in a similar place.
Margaret Walkup Good to see in you my feed Margaret! Thanks for the affirmation üôÇ

Tia Martinez Thanks Tia! You know, I've always led with hard truths - but over the years I've learned (especially watching masters like you) there's this delicate dance with truth-telling.¬†Go too light and we're just painting over problems that'll come back to haunt us. Go too heavy and we end up hurting and alienating the people we're trying to reach. It's really an art form, finding that sweet spot where truth can support justice but also open hearts instead of closing them.

LaShawn Rout√© Chatmon Love this LaShawn! One thing I didn't have space to write up here but thought a lot about is how different sources of capital that fund activity in the underground shape what it becomes. I've been thinking about the church offerings that funded the early stages of the civil rights movement, or the union dues that funded the labor movement. I wonder if our current spaces for building alternative models are too tied up in national foundations and other institutions invested in the current power structure to create true spaces of independent creativity and imagination. This seems to be especially true in education. And I wonder if the eventual commercialization of hip hop happened because traditional sources of capital started pouring in and changing the incentives.

Emmile Brack yes, public education is particularly tricky because there's such tremendous civic value to kids attending public institutions together, and many of the alternatives options create collective separation rather than unity. no easy answers!

Roxana Shirkhoda One of the perks of being a minister's husband is midnight philosophical riffs about the state of humanity. Shout out to Sally Steele for all the late night thought partnership to untangle this moment in history.

Tamika Mason, SHRM-SCP, SPH Thanks Tamika. 100%. We need new thinking and building to find a way to bridge between ALL of us and find an authentic solidarity. I know you've been doing this work since day one!

Pennie A. Glad this piece resonated. It's a great question about where to level up your business acumen.

Learning business acumen is a bit like learning jazz. While you can study music theory and practice scales, becoming a great musician requires playing with others and developing your ear through real experience. Similarly, while you can learn business fundamentals through study, most business acumen comes from hands-on experience working alongside seasoned practitioners.

That said, I suggest starting with Clay Christensen's \How Will You Measure Your Life?\" The book uses his business theories to offer guidelines for finding meaning
column4: giving you both an introduction to his business thinking and powerful life lessons. His Harvard Business School course \"Building and Sustaining a Successful Enterprise\" was formative for me - the theories help you understand the root causes of challenges that business leaders face.

Date: Your practical experience
Link: combined with studying frameworks that help you drive even more value
Message: will help develop the pattern recognition and judgment that defines true business acumen."

Marc Vermouth Thanks for this point. As someone who's worked in both sectors, I should have been clearer about the distinction between general management skills and sector-specific acumen.

Many professionals across both sectors develop similar management capabilities. Like learning to drive a car, you develop skills in handling the vehicle - leading teams, executing projects, setting goals. But business and social impact acumen are about knowing how to navigate to fundamentally different destinations. Business acumen requires deep understanding of how to create and capture value that customers will pay for, while social sector acumen requires mastery of both driving outcomes for communities in need and engaging donors who fund the work.

I find myself having to intentionally shift mindsets between my nonprofit and for-profit work - what seems an obvious decision in one context often becomes the opposite in the other. We might decline highly impactful activities in the for-profit context if consumers won't pay for them, while those same activities could drive both social impact and donor engagement in the nonprofit space. Companies often undervalue this social impact expertise, though we should push back on that bias.

Angela Parker I generally believe in sharing opportunities widely, with context, so people can make informed choices. We need thoughtful gardeners planting good seeds everywhere, especially in places experiencing growing pains around equity and belonging. But those gardeners deserve to go in eyes wide open, knowing what they're up against and ready for the challenge. I often wish these roles came with \nutrition labels\" that helped folks understand where they'll feel the most strain if they're committed to doing the work of centering folks at the bottom of the social hierarchy. All these roles require significant character

What a gift to be able to close this chapter with such profound gratitude and to celebrate the journey with the people who made it meaningful. Your letter beautifully captures both the impact you've had and the relationships that shaped you along the way. Looking forward to exploring what's next together as you bring your wealth of experience building transformative experiences to new ventures. Here's to beginnings that honor endings üôèüèΩ

Harriet Gardner Thank you and Tides for making the execution of this ambitious $25M fund possible! We couldn't have done it like we did without you. Truly a dream team of collaborators making magic happen here.
So proud to see this work recognized‚Äîsuch an impactful team effort! üëèüèΩüëèüèΩ
Sarah Di Troia That's a lot of pressure - what if I can't turn left? üòÖ
Ashley B. Stewart thank you! I've got a lot to say on this topic üòõ Looking forward to being in dialogue with committed leaders like you.

Julian R. Addo From my experience inside these companies, I've observed two key dynamics: Companies respond powerfully to the prospect of regulation or taxation - it's why they employ armies of professionals to avoid both. And real change (versus window dressing) happens when they empower people with lived experience for whom these issues are personal. There's also the role of consumer sentiment, but it cuts many ways and can be slippery.

I'm working on a longer piece about how internal change agents can transform institutions from within. Spoiler alert: it's incredibly hard. Follow me for more on reimagining corporate responsibility in ways that create lasting impact soon.

Julian R. Addo Your point about unequal starting points cuts to the heart of this. What does it mean when companies like Meta delegate the work of addressing systemic inequities to the institutions that precede them - knowing those very institutions have historically excluded people at the bottom of our social hierarchy? \Serving everyone\" becomes a way to outsource responsibility while maintaining progressive rhetoric."
When we say \all
column4: \" what history echoes forward? When the founders declared \"all men are created equal
column6: property-owning men. When companies today speak of \"serving everyone
column7: \" it's important to consider what exclusions might lurk beneath such universal language.

Date: Perhaps there's a deeper invitation here: to imagine what truly serving all could mean - not as comfortable rhetoric
Link: but as a revolutionary commitment to honor each person's full humanity. The path forward requires us to both acknowledge how \"all\" has been weaponized and still dare to dream of its true promise."

Message: Thanks Matthew Ganz. I wonder though - how meaningful can the legal risk really be when many of these programs never had the quotas that critics claim? At least at Google, I never encountered the hiring quotas that are now being cited as legal exposure, and I contributed to a lot of executive level DEI initiatives. Perhaps what we're witnessing isn't companies waking up to legal risk, but institutions finding comfortable justifications for retreat?

Zack Mellette Not yet! But we will soon. We'll put out the call when we're ready. First we need to create a more structured membership process so we can bound the group a bit. But we want as many Zack's rocking with us as possible üòõ

Sally Steele proud to be building this movement with you. And inspired by the leaders you've highlighted who've been creating these pathways long before us. The creativity and joy in our community gets me up and the morning and keeps me going.

Elizabeth Kreider Thanks for sharing your experience! And great idea for another article. I'm in the position now of looking for ways to contribute more directly to nonprofit leadership again, but transitioning from CSR is tough given the pay gaps between CSR work and the nonprofit sector (in my experience, total compensation can be more than double for CSR roles). One way I'm exploring this is through fractional work so that, while not necessarily getting to my market rate, I can be somewhere between the two. I'll put your article idea in the hopper!

Thanks, Jerome! I‚Äôm so glad you found the article valuable and appreciate the kind words. I‚Äôm intrigued by the 10% where your experience differs‚Äîthose nuanced tensions are often where the best learning happens. Would love to hear more about your experiences and insights!
Couldn't agree more, Tyler. When ChatGPT first suggested the name \Outdoorithm\" for our startup in 2022 (zero Google hits!)
column4: I knew we were entering a new era. Whether I'm pair programming our tech stack or exploring philosophical questions
column5: these tools consistently amaze me. You're absolutely right - the key isn't access
column6: it's curiosity and intentional application. Looking forward to seeing what 2025 brings!"

Message: 100% Erika R.! Marketing is such a powerful entry point into CSR - none of my favorite projects would have happened without talented storytellers like you. Plus, marketing roles are often more accessible and can be a great way to unlock CSR from the inside. Miss collaborating with you!

My brother! Love that to the hour we both dropped posts about the exact same thing - helping folks understand how this CSR game works. I told folks in my piece, skip the front door (it's locked), go find a window. As you beautifully point out, it is not a meritocracy! Your commitment to being a gate-opener not a gatekeeper is exactly what this field needs. Keep shining your light. üôåüèæ

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/breaking-corporate-social-responsibility-insiders-guide-justin-steele-ayhme
The system needs to change. Grateful for your family's powerful advocacy on this.

Eduvators The weather widget nailed it today! Light drizzle in the morning followed by perfect weather for a Hetch Hetchy hike with the Outdoorithm Collective crew. Knowing what to expect helped us plan a perfect first day in Yosemite and keep everyone safe and comfortable.

Nicole Tinson That‚Äôs exactly it. This work is a lifelong calling without a clear finish line. Good and evil will always be tugging at the world, and our role is to pull, as best we can, in the direction of goodness and light.

Jennifer Atala Thank you for your thoughtful comment and for all the important work you‚Äôre doing. The question of when to exit the system is such a profound one, and it‚Äôs something I‚Äôve wrestled with myself throughout my career.

One of the greatest temptations in this work is to martyr oneself‚Äîto leave as a statement or to keep fighting battles that lead to burnout rather than meaningful progress. Viktor Frankl‚Äôs Man‚Äôs Search for Meaning has been a guiding light for me in those moments. He writes about finding purpose in suffering, and that reflection often gave me the resolve to stay, to cultivate the internal capacity to endure setbacks, and to focus on the long, hard work of creating change from within.

That said, suffering for suffering‚Äôs sake isn‚Äôt the goal. If the environment overwhelms you or progress becomes impossible, leaving isn‚Äôt a failure‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategy. I‚Äôve found that it‚Äôs about balance: staying only if you can still move the needle and grow through the challenges. There‚Äôs no shame in stepping away to spend your energy and talents elsewhere if the system resists all efforts for meaningful change.

Daniel Di Giusto 
Thank you! Absolutely‚Äîthere are situations where talent or product can be more valuable than money, but the real magic happens when you combine them. Nonprofits need cash‚Äîit‚Äôs like fuel for the car. But when you add talent or product, you‚Äôre not just filling the tank‚Äîyou‚Äôre helping to build or enhance the car itself.

For example, at the Equal Justice Initiative, cash supported the National Memorial to Peace and Justice, but pairing that with creative talent brought the Lynching in America project to life, from the website to documentary content to interactive tools. These combinations are where real impact starts.

That said, the tensions in corporate social impact apply no matter the resources‚Äînavigating them is always part of the work.

Jaime Hansen Thank you for raising such important points. Separating role from self is one of the hardest parts of leading in these tensions. Companies/foundations often leverage your personal identity when it‚Äôs convenient and then turn it against you when critiques arise.

The roles we play in advancing social impact‚Äîwhether as leaders, advocates, or connectors‚Äîare not the totality of who we are, even when the work feels deeply personal. Recognizing this can provide resilience. It allows us to respond constructively to challenges aimed at our roles without internalizing them as reflections of our worth. This is especially important when navigating emotionally charged issues where reactions can feel intensely personal.

As for re-traumatization, it often happens in environments where lived experience is tokenized rather than valued. When empowered with decision-making authority, lived experience becomes a strength, enabling you to align actions with what you know to be true. But in environments where it‚Äôs treated as symbolic, it can leave you excluded, devalued, and ultimately retraumatized. These environments are rarely healthy, and I do my best to avoid them when I can.

It's been a privilege rocking with you Peta-Gay Clarke. You were absolutely one of those leaders who sharpened my thinking and made me a better leader. And excellent point about trust. If you bring folks with lived experience on but don't hand them the keys to the car, you're forcing them into an advocacy role that often leads to marginalization and exacts a toll.

Candice Morgan Yes! All of this. We're holding these tensions not in a static environment but a dynamic one that changes with every cultural, political, and economic shift. Very much appreciated our conversations over the years sharpening each other's approach.

Thank you for creating this space for us, Alex. I was inspired by seeing how other Black men navigate and thrive in outdoor spaces‚Äîgrateful for the experience and the community you brought together.
I think it was! I still remember that visit fondly. Congrats on your decade plus of leadership at AACSA Milan.

Wow Shaun Tai, super humbled by this post. Tough seasons of life are when you find out who's really riding for you. I appreciate all the affirmation. Playing a small part in your and BRIDGEGOOD's ascension has been a privilege.

I'm someone who has always felt the truth in my body. I can try to suppress it, but it's there, weighing on me. The first time I stepped into BRIDGEGOOD after Chelsea Seabron encouraged me to check it out, I knew there was something special. Your heart and intention was clear. The community surrounding BRIDGEGOOD was nothing short of special. I knew this was the kind of thing that deserves to be elevated but is too often overlooked. 

Thank you for all the amazing memories (and the help with several digital art projects, including the Outdoorithm logo!). Let's keep finding ways to work together and take those #moonshots.
Awesome to see you writing such impactful books Alliah. So needed. Just bought a copy :)
Raquel M. Love what Hood Hikers is doing! Thanks for putting them on our radar.

Thanks Myrian! This does look like a great fit for Outdoorithm Collective once we get everything squared away. Glad to know great programs like Route to Parks exists. Our first four group trips have all been to California State Parks!
Lex Leifheit thank you for signing up!! lots of new features and community building opportunities coming soon. we'd love to have you involved.

Cate Gustafson thank you for sharing those memories! we hope our kids one day will look back and be thankful we hauled them outdoors so often (they always love it in the moment but it's not always easy convincing them to go out again). and yes, we need more ways to bridge and build community! gathering in beautiful outdoor spaces turns out to be a great way to do this.
Hi Jon, what a beautiful site! Great job on the promo video. We'll follow up!

James Dong great reminder of how varied the market of campers is. we're constantly trying to simplify and strike the balance between giving folks what they need and not completely overwhelming them. super tough. the push into group trips is partly out of a realization that some folks just need to sign up to join a group that will provide most of the gear and teach them what they need to know. i'll work on the three slide version of the deck for folks who just wanna jump out there. great suggestion.

Lauren, we're definitely on the same wavelength! We're excited about the ways AI is going to simplify the planning process and make camping even more accessible. The next tool we're working on is a matchmaking tool to help you find the best campgrounds and plan road trips.

Reservations are definitely a challenge, but we're developing a tool that will notify you when reservations become available at your desired campgrounds. We understand the desire to keep things fair for everyone, so we're working within the existing rules for public campgrounds, which prevent anyone booking sites on your behalf.

Yvonne Vargas Dope! What's your cousin's company? I feel like we're one step from overlanding, but the idea of heading out the door with four kids in the back not knowing exactly where we're going to end up camping that night is just a bit too much for us üòÄ
Watch out Kristy, we're eyeing group trips in Atlanta, and you know we're going to try and get you out there üòÅ We're definitely more on the glamping end of the spectrum!

Marilyn Higi Kincaid Great ideas Marilyn!! We also volunteer at BAWT and love their work :) We'll definitely put another slide up on where folks can look for gear rentals as we agree, its an important resource for folks exploring this for the first time. Sally has also connected with Seraph, so great minds think alike! Keep these awesome ideas coming.
Inspiring!
Yo, what a great story Hoop! My actual little bro lived with us for the past four months, and it's a commitment on all sides. Never knew you did that. #respect
yeah Hoop! Zoom is lucky to have you. always proud to see you paving the way for the community.
The entire small business portion wouldn't have been possible without your vision and leadership Sam. Congrats!!

The University of Virginia has had the highest graduation rate of African American students of any public university for the past 15 years.  The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education publishes an annual assessment of African American graduation rates across the country:

[http://www.jbhe.com/features/50_blackstudent_gradrates.html|leo://plh/http%3A*3*3www%2Ejbhe%2Ecom*3features*350_blackstudent_gradrates%2Ehtml/owUL?_t=tracking_disc]

The primary reason for the University of Virginia's success has been the Office of African American Affair's (OAAA) Peer Advisor Program, where every incoming African American student is paired with an upperclass mentor for the entire year with a structured outreach program.  I co-chaired the PA program as a senior in college and can attest to the profound impact it has on student retention.  I would suggest getting in touch with the OAAA to inquire about the structure of their program.
